intro: Potentilla tapetodes var. decidua, commonly known as the deciduous cinquefoil, is a flowering plant belonging to the Rosaceae family. It is characterized by its compound leaves with five leaflets, and it produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant is native to regions of Europe and Asia, often found in rocky or woodland soils. It is a perennial shrub that typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters. The deciduous variety is distinguished by its shedding of leaves in autumn, unlike its evergreen counterparts.
